content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would analyze this situation strategically to maximize my earnings over 75 rounds. This game seems to be a mix of the classic Prisoner's Dilemma and Chicken games.

If we assume that both players are rational and selfish (i.e., they always want to earn the maximum possible), it might seem like choosing R would be the optimal move because if my opponent chooses B, I get 42$ while they only get 0$. However, this is not a guaranteed outcome, as my opponent could choose R and get 45$, leaving me with 0$.

On the other hand, choosing B seems risky initially since it results in earning 12$ per round if my opponent also chooses B. But remember, if my opponent chooses R while I choose B, I still get 42$, which is better than getting 0$ if they choose R and I choose R.

However, the key here is that the game has 75 rounds. Over a large number of rounds, choosing R would result in missed opportunities to earn 12$ per round when my opponent also chooses B. This means that even though choosing R can sometimes lead to higher earnings per round, it may not be the best long-term strategy due to the missed opportunities for earning 12$ per round with a B choice.

Given these considerations and assuming both players are rational, it seems likely that my opponent will also choose B since choosing R would lead them to miss out on earning 12$ per round when I choose B. Therefore, I might also choose B (B{) in this situation to maximize my earnings over the long term.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

As a human player, I have just experienced a situation where my choice (B) resulted in a higher payoff for me compared to my opponent's choice (R). However, since I assume my opponent to be rational and selfish, I expect them to learn from their mistake and choose B on the next round. This is because choosing R again would lead them to miss out on earning 42$ if I choose B in this round.

Therefore, considering that my opponent will likely choose B in the next round, I might also choose R (R{) as a counter-strategy to maximize my earnings since I already know their expected choice is now B. This way, if they stick with their new strategy and choose B, I will earn 45$ for choosing R while they only get 12$. If they switch back to R, I still earn 0$, but that's a risk I am willing to take because I already earned 42$ in the previous round.

Of course, this strategy assumes that my opponent is rational and will stick with their new strategy in the future. If they have a tendency to switch back to R after experiencing a loss or change their behavior unpredictably, then it may be difficult to make an accurate prediction and optimize earnings. But for now, I choose R (R{) as my next move based on this strategic reasoning.

As a human player, I have just experienced a situation where both me and my opponent chose the same option (B), resulting in a lower payoff of 12$ per round for both players. Since we are both rational and selfish players, it might seem like either player could switch their choice to R to earn a higher payoff if the other player sticks with B. However, since we both have already experienced the consequences of choosing B, there is a chance that one or both of us may stick with our choice out of habit or a belief that the other will change their strategy.

In this situation, I cannot predict with certainty what my opponent will choose in the next round. They might stick with B (B{}) due to habit or a belief that I will switch to R, or they might switch to R (R{}) to exploit my perceived tendency to continue choosing B. To maximize my earnings over the long term, I need to make an educated guess about what my opponent will do and choose accordingly.

Since I have already chosen B twice in a row, there is a chance that my opponent might assume that I am likely to stick with B in the next round due to habit. To exploit this potential expectation and maximize my earnings over the long term, I might switch my choice to R (R{}) for the next round. This way, if my opponent indeed sticks with B due to habit, I will earn 45$ while they only get 12$. If my opponent switches to R as well, both of us will get 0$. However, this strategy assumes that my opponent is rational and follows a predictable pattern, which may not always be the case.

Ultimately, it's impossible for me to accurately predict what my opponent will do in the next round due to the inherent unpredictability of human behavior, especially in repeated games with no clear dominant strategy. In such cases, the best I can do is make an educated guess and choose R (R{}) for this round as a potential counter-strategy to maximize my earnings over the long term.
